perturbation.original_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall be responsible for the timely filing of such amendments, and for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning her or it contained therein, but shall not be responsible for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning the other, except to the extent that she or it knows or has reason to believe that such information is inaccurate.
perturbation.changed_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall endeavor to be responsible for the timely filing of such amendments, and to the best of their understanding, ensure the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning her or it contained therein, but shall not be responsible for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning the other, only if they have definitive proof that such information is inaccurate.
perturbation.explanation: The change replaces 'shall be responsible' with 'shall endeavor to be responsible' and adds 'to the best of their understanding' and 'only if they have definitive proof that such information is inaccurate.' This introduces ambiguity and weakens the legal obligation for accurate and timely filings.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification contradicts the strict requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, specifically Rule 13d-1, which mandates accurate and timely filings. By introducing 'endeavor to be responsible' and 'to the best of their understanding,' the agreement allows for potential negligence or inaccuracies, undermining the intent of the law to ensure transparency and accountability in ownership reporting. Additionally, definitive proof introduces higher evidentiary standards when the legal standard is ‘knows or has reason to believe’.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 17 CFR § 240.13d-1 - Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. | Electronic Code of Federal Regulations (e-CFR) | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you 17 CFR § 240.13d-1 - Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. CFR Table of Popular Names prev | next § 240.13d-1 Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. (a) Any person who, after acquiring directly or indirectly the beneficial ownership of any equity security of a class which is specified in paragraph (i)(1) of this section , is directly or indirectly the beneficial owner of more than five percent of the class shall, within five business days after the date of the acquisition, file with the Commission, a statement containing the information required by Schedule 13D (§ 240.13d-101) . (b) (1) A person who would otherwise be obligated under paragraph (a) of this section to file a statement on Schedule 13D (§ 240.13d-101) may, in lieu thereof, file with the Commission, a short-form statement on Schedule 13G (§ 240.13d-102), Provided, That: (i) Such person has acquired such securities in the ordinary course of the person's business and not with the purpose nor with the effect of changing or influencing the control of the issuer , nor in connection with or as a participant in any transaction having such purpose or effect, including any transaction subject to § 240.13d-3(b) and (ii) Such person is: (A) A broker or dealer registered under section 15 of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78o ); (B) A bank as defined in section 3(a)(6) of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78c ); (C) An insurance company as defined in section 3(a)(19) of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78c ); (D) An investment company registered under section 8 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 ( 15 U.S.C. 80a-8 ); (E) Any person registered as an investment adviser under Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ( 15 U.S.C. 80b-3 ) or under the laws of any state; (F) An employee benefit plan as defined in Section 3(3) of the Employee Retirement Income Security A
perturbation.justification: The original contract language states the parties 'shall be responsible' for timely and accurate filings. The change weakens this obligation by using 'shall endeavor to be responsible' and 'to the best of their understanding', introducing ambiguity. The law explanation argues this contradicts the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, specifically Rule 13d-1, which mandates accurate and timely filings. Scraped Law Snippet 1, 17 CFR § 240.13d-1(a), states that 'any person...is directly or indirectly the beneficial owner of more than five percent of the class shall, within five business days after the date of the acquisition, file with the Commission, a statement containing the information required by Schedule 13D'. The change to 'endeavor' weakens the obligation to file accurately and on time, moving it away from the strict filing requirements implied by the law. The addition of 'only if they have definitive proof that such information is inaccurate' introduces a higher evidentiary standard than 'knows or has reason to believe' in the original. This means parties can avoid responsibility for inaccuracies unless definitive proof exists, further weakening the original obligation. While the snippet itself doesn't explicitly state 'strict liability' or use the word 'endeavor', the change clearly undermines the prompt and absolute requirement to file accurate statements, thus creating a contradiction.
